Award.AwardTitle: The Evolution of an Engineering Problem Solver

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research project will help a team of engineering faculty and educational researchers plan to collect long term data to understand changes in student learning for a unique curriculum in Minnesota. The Iron Range Engineering program draws from community colleges and engages students in a self-directed, project-based learning curriculum that involves local industries that need to hire engineers.

The broader significance and importance of this project will be to investigate the effectively of alternative curricular models that have rarely been implemented in the United States. The Iron Range Engineering model has the potential to serve as a model for groups of students who are under-represented in most engineering programs or who desire to build on previous real-world experiences in obtaining an engineering degree. This project overlaps with NSF's strategic goals of transforming the frontiers through preparation of an engineering workforce with new capabilities and expertise. Additionally NSF's goal of innovating for society is enabled by supporting the development of innovative learning systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A study was conducted to analyze how engineering students in a Problem Based Learning (PBL) curricula develop as problem solvers. In specific, issues of identity, technical competence acquistion, success in engineering practice, and self-directed learning ability were studied. Quantitative comparisons were made between PBL students and traditional engineering students. Qualitative interviews and analysis were conducted on PBL graduates. The following outcomes were identified: 

Key Outcome 1 - PBL graduates and their supervisors report equal or higher levels of engineering outcome attributes in engineering practice.

Key Outcome 2 - PBL graduates pass the FE exam at or above national pass rates

Key Outcome 3 - PBL graduates language use shows higher levels of engineering identity.

Key Outcome 4 - PBL graduates language use shows lower levels of engineering characteristics.

Key Outcome 5 - PBL graduates show signficant growth in self-directed learning abilities during upper division. Non-PBL graduates do not show significant growth.

Key Outcome 6 - A model for how PBL graduates experience self-directed learning has been developed. This model is included.

These results have implications for the future of engineering education. Decision makers in engineering education should contemplate the results of this work as they consider implementation of PBL curricular models. 


Last Modified: 12/03/2015
Modified by: Ronald R Ulseth
